abstract.text: An abstract class representing a stream.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: This class’s interface is common to all Cocoa stream classes, including its concrete subclasses
and

objects provide an easy way to read and write data to and from a variety of media in a device-independent way. You can create stream objects for data located in memory, in a file, or on a network (using sockets), and you can use stream objects without loading all of the data into memory at once.
By default,
instances that aren’t file-based are non-seekable, one-way streams (although custom seekable subclasses are possible). After you provide or consume data, you can’t retrieve the data from the stream.

is an abstract class, incapable of instantiation and intended for you to subclass it. It publishes a programmatic interface that all subclasses must adopt and provide implementations for. The two Apple-provided concrete subclasses of
and
, are suitable for most purposes. However, there might be situations when you want a peer subclass to
and
. For example, you might want a class that implements a full-duplex (two-way) stream, or a class whose instances are capable of seeking through a stream.
All subclasses must fully implement the following methods:
and
Implement
to open the stream for reading or writing and make the stream available to the client directly or, if the stream object is scheduled on a run loop, to the delegate. Implement

to close the stream and remove the stream object from the run loop, if necessary. A closed stream should still be able to accept new properties and report its current properties. Once you close a stream, you can’t reopen it.
Return and set the delegate. By a default, a stream object must be its own delegate; so a
message with an argument of
should restore this delegate. Don’t retain the delegate to prevent retain cycles.
To learn about delegates and delegation, read "Delegation" in Cocoa Fundamentals Guide.
and
Implement
to schedule the stream object on the specified run loop for the specified mode. Implement
to remove the object from the run loop. See the documentation of the
class for details. Once the stream object for an open stream is scheduled on a run loop, it is the responsibility of the subclass as it processes stream data to send
messages to its delegate.
and
Implement these methods to return and set, respectively, the property value for the specified key. You may add custom properties, but be sure to handle all properties defined by
as well.
and
Implement
to return the current status of the stream as a
constant; you may define new
constants, but be sure to handle the system defined constants properly. Implement
to return an
object representing the current error. You might decide to return a custom
object that can provide complete and localized information about the error.

Returns the receiver’s property for a given key.
Closes the receiver.
Removes the receiver from a given run loop running in a given mode.
Opens the receiving stream.
Attempts to set the value of a given property of the receiver and returns a Boolean value that indicates whether the value is accepted by the receiver.
Creates and returns by reference a bound pair of input and output streams.

object and
object for a socket connection with a given host on a given port.

Schedules the receiver on a given run loop in a given mode.
Sets the receiver’s delegate.

to specify the kind of stream event.

and setting properties with
